File.Title: The Nigral Projection to Predorsal Bundle Cells in the Superior Colliculus of the Rat
ABSTRACT

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
For ease of description, the experiments have been divided into three parts.

The goal of the first part was to determine, by retrograde and anterograde tracers, the laminar distribution and extent of overlap of the predorsal bundle cells and the terminal field of the nigrotectal tract.

In the second part, the nigrotectal tract and the predorsal bundle cells were labeled for electron microscopy either in separate or in single animals in order to characterize the synaptic contacts between these two pathways.

In the final part, immunocytochemical methods were used to characterize, with the light and electron microscopes, the GAEiAergic terminals in contact with predorsal bundle cells that had been labeled by retrograde transport.
Laminar distribution of predorsal bundle cells

For the purpose of comparing the laminar distribution of predorsal bundle cells with that of a source of input, the nigrotectal tract, it was important to label the dendrites as well as the somas of the predorsal bundle cells.
For this reason, injections of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) were placed into the predorsal bundle as it decussates beneath the oculomotor nucleus.
Injections at this site homogeneously fill the somas and dendrites of large numbers of cells in the superior colliculus by retrograde transport and/or diffusion (May and Hall, '84).
Nine rats were used for these experiments.

Prior to surgery, the rats were anesthetized with either intraperitoneal injections of sodium pentobarbital (55 mg/kg) supplemented by intramuscular injections of chloral hydrate (0.1-0.4 cc), or with a combination of intraperitoneal injections of sodium pentobarbital (16.25 mg/kg) and ketamine hydrochloride (67 mg/kg).

The surgical procedure consisted of exposing the cerebellum caudal to the injection site and then, under stereotaxic control, advancing a horizontal Hamilton syringe rostrally to the level of the decussation.
The final placement of the syringe was checked by stimulating electrically through the tip of the insulated syringe needle to initiate eye movements.

A total volume of 0.4-1 p1 of either 60% HRP and 2% dimethylsulfoxide in saline or 60% HRP in saline was injected while the syringe tip was moved horizontally over a distance of 1 mm from rostra1 to caudal along the midline of the decussation.

Following survival times of 2-4 days, the rats were deeply anesthetized with 1 cc of sodium pentobarbital and perfused through the heart with phosphate-buffered saline (pH 7.4), followed by a solution of 1.5% paraformaldehyde and 1.5% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4).
The brains were postfixed overnight, then blocked in the coronal or sagittal plane, and cut with a vibratome into 50 or 100 p,m thick sections.
The sections were treated with 3,3'-diaminobenzidine and intensified with heavy metals, either nickel or a combination of nickel and cobalt (Adams, '811, and imidazole (Straw, '82).
The sections then were mounted on slides and counterstained.
Selected labeled cells were drawn with the aid of a camera lucida.
Most of our data concerning inputs to predorsal bundle cells were obtained by studying one component of this crossed pathway, the tectospinal cells.

To determine the distribution and morphology of the tectospinal cells, a 0.5-2 pl solution of 50% HRP dissolved either in saline or in saline with 2% dimethylsulfoxide was injected into the spinal cord between the first and second vertebrae in eight rats.
The general surgical and histological procedures were the same as those followed for the animals with injections into the decussation.

Labeled cells were drawn at a magnification of 1,000 times with the aid of a camera lucida, and their areas were measured with an electronic planimeter to obtain an estimate of their size distribution.
Of the eight rats in this series of experiments, seven also were used in the study of the inputs to tectospinal cells.

These latter brains were processed both for retrograde transport from the spinal cord and, in addition, for anterograde transport of either Phaseolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHA-L), HRP, or wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to HRP (WGA-HRP) from substantia nigra, or for glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD) immunocytochemistry.
Some of the sections from each of these cases were processed for electron microscopy.
The additional procedures for these cases will be described in later sections.
Terminal distribution of the nigrotectal pathway
The terminal distribution of the nigrotectal pathway was examined with the use of either HRP (five rats), WGA-HRP (six rats), or PHA-L (five rats) as an anterograde tracer.

In all cases, either a syringe (2 rats) or a pipette (14 rats) was oriented at an angle of 20" from vertical in the coronal plane and lowered through the cortex and medial geniculate body to reach substantia nigra pars reticulata.
For the iontophoretic injections, the HRP or WGA-HRP was dissolved in a solution of 0.3 M tris buffer with 0.05 M KCl (pH 7.4).
The injections were made by passing a positive current of 2 pA through a 30 pm diameter pipette tip for from 20 to 60 minutes.
The pressure injections were made with a Hamilton syringe and consisted of 0.2 p1 of 50% or 70% HRP in saline.
The survival times and HRP histochemical methods were the same as those described in the previous section.

In the experiments that utilized PHA-L, a 2.5% solution of biotinylated PHA-L (Vector) was dissolved in distilled water and injected by passing a current of 5 pA through the 30 pm tip of a pipette for periods ranging from 40 to 60 minutes.
After survival times of 3-5 days, the rats were deeply anesthetized and perfused through the heart.

In material containing PHA-L, several combinations of fixatives were tried in an effort to optimize preservation of the fine structure for subsequent electron microscopy, while optimizing the immunocytochemical labeling of the PHA-L.

These combinations were: 3.5% paraformaldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (one rat), 4% paraformaldehyde and 0.25% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (one rat), periodate-lysine-paraformaldehyde (McLean and Nakane, '74) (one rat), and 2.5% paraformaldehyde and 0.05% glutaraldehyde in phosphate buffer (two rats).
Volumes of fixative ranging from 600 to 700 ml were used.
Of the fixative solutions we tried, the 2.5% paraformaldehyde and 0.05% glutaraldehyde gave the best ultrastructural preservation of the tissue while maintaining good immunocytochemical labeling.
In every case, the fixatives were flushed from the rat 1 hour following perfusion with a solution of phosphatebuffered saline.
Fifty micron thick sections were cut on a vibratome.

Sections were incubated in solutions of 5, 10, and 20% dimethylsulfoxide (10 minutes each), and then frozen and thawed from 2 to 5 times in the final solution to increase penetration of the antibodies.
Two rounds of freezing and thawing of the tissue was the best compromise between good penetration of the antibodies and preservation of fine structure.
For the PHA-L immunocytochemistry, the primary antibody solution was 1:1,000 biotinylated anti-PHA-L from goat in phosphate buffer with 1% normal goat serum.
The sections were incubated in this solution for 2 hours at room temperature, with agitation, overnight at 4"C, and then for 1 hour the next day at room temperature, again with agitation.
Next, the sections were washed in phosphate buffer and incubated with agitation in a solution of 1:lOO avidin and phosphate buffer with 0.1% bovine serum albumin for 1 hour at room temperature.
This procedure was repeated with 1:lOO biotinylated HRP.
After rinsing in phosphate buffer, the sections were placed in a solution of 0.1% glutaraldehyde in phosphate buffer for 5 minutes.
They were then washed in phosphate buffer and incubated with diaminobenzidine as described for the experiments that used HRP.
PHA-L label was found throughout the thickness of the 50 pm thick sections.
The sections were either mounted on slides and counterstained with cresyl violet to demonstrate the tectal layers or processed for electron microscopy, according to the methods described below.
Nigrotectal terminations on predorsal bundle cells

To characterize the synaptic contacts between nigrotectal terminals and the predorsal bundle cells, the retrograde transport of HRP from the spinal cord was combined with the anterograde transport of either WGA-HRP or PHA-L from the substantia nigra in single animals.
When WGAHRP was used as the anterograde tracer (one rat), reaction of the tissue with diaminobenzidine could be used to demonstrate both the nigrotectal terminals and the tectospinal cells.

When PHA-L was used as the anterograde tracer (three rats), immunocytochemical procedures were used to link the PHA-L with HRP; then, a reaction with diaminobenzidine was used to demonstrate both the nigrotectal terminals and the tectospinal cells.
The latter method had the advantage of allowing control sections to be prepared that were reacted with diaminobenzidine without undergoing the preceding PHA-L immunocytochemistry.
The control sections were examined to ensure that the spinal cord injections did not also label spinotectal terminals that could be confounded with nigrotectal terminals (see below).
When the reactions were completed, the sections were either mounted on slides and counterstained, or processed for electron microscopy.

For electron microscopy, the sections were postiixed in osmium tetroxide, stained en bloc with uranyl acetate, dehydrated in an ethanol series, and embedded in Epon or Durcupan resin between glass slides coated with dimethyldichlorosilane.

Regions were selected for examination with the electron microscope by drawing with a camera lucida all of the labeled tectospinal cells and adjacent terminals in the sections that were embedded between dimethyldichlorosilane-coated slides.
Interesting regions of these 50 pm sections were also photographed.
Areas of the sections that contained labeled terminals in close apposition to labeled cells were mounted on blocks of resin and cut into 5 pm thick sections.
These thinner sections were dried onto slides and examined with the light microscope to locate terminals that had been drawn in the 50 pm sections.
The areas containing these terminals were drawn again and occasionally photographed.
Selected 5 pm sections were remounted on resin blocks and cut into serial thin sections.
The serial sections were collected on formvarcoated slot grids and examined with the electron microscope.
This procedure for examining the same structures with both the light and electron microscopes is illustrated in Figures 1 and 2.
Figure 1 shows a sequence of pictures following a terminal found in close apposition to a tectospinal cell in a 50 pm section with the light microscope (Fig.
lA), to a 5 Fm thick section (Fig. lB), and finally to electron micrographs of thin sections (Fig. lC,D).
The terminal was labeled with WGA-HRP from an injection in substantia nigra and the tectospinal cell was labeled from an injection of HRP in the spinal cord.

Figure 2A illustrates a camera lucida drawing of a tectospinal cell filled with HRP by retrograde transport and closely associated terminal arbors that were labeled with PHA-L following an injection in substantia nigra.
Figure 2B and C shows two focal planes through the 50 pm section drawn in A.
Two distinct segments of the terminal arbors indicated by long and short arrows in Figure 2A can be identified in the photographs of Figure 2B and C.
Figure 2D and E illustrates two focal planes of a 5 pm section subsequently taken from the 50 pm section.
The asterisks indicate two terminal segments that can be identified in both the 50 and 5 Fm sections.
Parts of these latter two segments are illustrated again in the electron micrographs of Figure 2F and G.
GABAergic input to predorsal bundle cells
In a find part of the study, GAD-immunoreactive terminals that contact identified predorsd bundle cells were examined to provide a basis for comparisons with the nigrotectal terminals.
In one rat, only the GAD-immunoreactive terminals were labeled, whereas in three rats both the terminals and tectospinal cells were labeled in the same sections.
In these experiments, the rats were perfused with 600-700 ml of a solution of 2.5% paraformaldehyde and 0.05% glutaraldehyde in phosphate buffer.
After 1 hour, the fixative was flushed from the brain with phosphatebuffered saline.
The brain was stored in this solution overnight.
The next day 50 pm thick sections were cut using a vibratome.
The sections from animals in which the tectospinal cells had been labeled by retrograde transport of HRP were processed with diaminobenzidine.
Subsequently, the sections were soaked for 10 minutes in each of a series of solutions of 5, 10, and 20% dimethylsulfoxide in phosphate buffer.
Then, to increase penetration, the sections were frozen and thawed from 2 to 5 times while in the 20% solution.

For the immunocytochemistry, the sections were washed in the phosphate buffer and incubated in the primary antibody solution of 1:2,000 GAD antiserum from sheep (Oertel et al., '81) and phosphate buffer with 1% normal rabbit serum.
The sections were incubated in this solution for 2 hours at room temperature with agitation, overnight at 4"C, and 1 hour the next day at room temperature with agitation.
Control sections were incubated in a solution of 1:1,000 preimmune sheep serum and buffer with 1% normal rabbit serum.

Following incubation in the primary antibody solution, the sections were washed in phosphate buffer and incubated with agitation in a solution of 1:lOO anti-sheep IgG from rabbit and buffer with 1% normal rabbit serum for 1 hour at room temperature.

Then, the sections were washed in phosphate buffer and incubated in a solution of 1:500 peroxidase-antiperoxidase from sheep and phosphate buffer with 1% normal rabbit serum for 1 hour at room temperature with agitation.
The sections were washed again and postfixed in a solution of 0.1% glutaraldehyde in buffer for 5 minutes.
After a buffer rinse, the sections were reacted with diaminobenzidine.
When the retrograde transport of HRP and GAD immunocytochemistry were combined in single sections, only the first of the diaminobenzidine reactions was intensified with a heavy metal.
After the reactions, the sections were either mounted on slides and counterstained or processed for electron microscopy using the methods described in the previous section.
Control experiments
The combinations of methods used in these experiments permitted the use of certain types of control experiments.
In the experiments with paired injections, spinotectal terminals could be mistaken for nigrotectal terminals if the spinal cord injections of HRP labeled the spinotectal tract.
We used two controls for this potential source of error.
First, we looked for terminals in cases with spinal cord injections that were not paired with injections in substantia nigra.

Second, in the cases in which the spinal cord injection of HRP was paired with an injection of PHA-L in substantia nigra, some sections were reacted with diaminobenzidine to reveal the HRP reaction product, but were not processed immunocytochemically to reveal the PHA-L.
These control sections were then examined for labeled terminals.
An additional source of error might be injections of the substantia nigra that labeled tectal efferent cells that could be mistaken for tectospinal cells.
Controls for this possibility were provided by the experiments in which injections into substantia nigra were not paired with spinal cord injections.

Finally, in our cases in which GAD immunocytochemistry was combined with HRP injections in the spinal cord, control sections were labeled with diaminobenzidine to reveal the HRP reaction product and then incubated in a solution of preimmune serum (1:1,000) instead of the GAD antibody, and examined for spuriously labeled terminals.
Definition of the layers in the superior colliculus
For the layers of the superior colliculus in the rat, we have used the designations suggested by Weiner ('86).
The justification for this choice and its relationships to the designations used in other studies have been discussed in previous papers (Wallace, '86; Bickford and Hall, '89).

Results.S: RESULTS
Laminar distribution of predorsal bundle cells

TTE.S: Following injections of HRP into the decussation of the predorsal bundle, large numbers of cells in the intermediate grey layer were filled with reaction product.
The cells filled by this procedure varied in size.

The dendrites as well as the somas of many of the labeled cells were homogeneously filled and, as a result, with these injections it was possible to estimate the laminar distribution of the receptive surfaces of a large sample of the cells that give rise to the predorsal bundle.
Most of the predorsal bundle cells had four or five primary dendrites, which, for the largest cells, extended as far as 800 pm in the mediolateral or dorsoventral dimensions.
Photographs of a sample of these cells are shown in Figure 3.
Reaction product filled even the finely tapered tips of the dendrites; while the density of spines was variable, they were filled on many of the cells.
Most of these spines were located on the distal dendrites.
Many of the distal dendrites also had a beaded appearance.

In the lateral part of the intermediate grey layer, the dendrites extended radially from the somas, whereas in the more compressed medial part of the layer, the dendrites extended primarily in the medial, lateral, and dorsal dimensions.
Regardless of their size or the orientation of their dendrites, the vast majority of predorsal bundle cells was restricted to the intermediate grey layer as defined by Weiner ('86).

Results.S: This distribution, which was described in detail in a previous paper (Bickford and Hall, '89), is illustrated in Figure 4.
This figure is a composite drawing of a sample of cells labeled in one animal following an injection into the predorsal bundle decussation.

The most distal dendrites of a few cells extended dorsally into stratum opticum or ventrally into the intermediate white and deep grey layers, but none extended through stratum opticum to reach the superficial grey layer.
In our material, predorsal bundle cells were most numerous in the lateral extreme, or flank (Weiner, '86), of the intermediate grey layer.
The arrows in Figures 3A and 4 indicate this area.
In the flank, there is no overlying superficial grey layer and the dendrites of some predorsal bundle cells extended to the pial surface (Figs. 3 and 4).

TTE.S: In several experiments, the injections were placed in the cervical spinal cord rather than the decussation in order to label just the tectospinal component of the predorsal bundle pathway.
Following these injections, the HRP reaction product was granular and was confined primarily to the somas and proximal dendrites of the cells in the superior colliculus.
However, as in the cases with decussation injections, cell somas that varied over a wide size range were labeled.

Results.S: In one experiment, all of the labeled tectospinal cells in alternate sections through the superior colliculus were drawn and measured.
In this sample of 178 cells, the soma areas ranged from 127 to 877 km2 (mean = 375 pm2).
This size distribution is shown in Figure 5.
Also, as in the cases with decussation injections, the somas of the labeled cells were restricted almost entirely to the intermediate grey layer.
Since these cells were labeled with a granular reaction product that was confined to the somas and proximal dendrites, we could not determine the extent of their dendritic fields.
Terminal distribution of the nigrotectal pathway

TTE.S: The trajectory of the axons from substantia nigra pars reticulata and their terminal distribution in the superior colliculus are illustrated for a case with a nigral injection of WGA-HRP in Figure 6 and for a case with an injection of PHA-L in Figure 7.
Photographs of the series of substantia nigra injection sites from the cases that will be described are shown in Figures 7 and 8.
In all of these cases, the axons exited from the dorsal border of substantia nigra pars reticulata and then extended dorsomedially, in the direction of the central grey.
Just beneath the ipsilateral superior colliculus the axons turned to reach the lateral border of the deep tectal layers.

In each case, a large number of axons terminated in the lateral flank of the intermediate grey layer, whereas others continued medially in the mediolaterally oriented band of fibers that forms the intermediate white layer, and terminated in more medial parts of the overlying grey layer.
Other axons traveled medial within the intermediate grey layer itself to reach their terminal zone.
The terminals in this layer were particularly dense within sublayer b, which is distinguished by bundles of rostrocaudal fibers (Weiner, '86; Bickford and Hall, '89).
Here, they formed a patchy distribution.
A small number of fibers crossed in the commissure of the superior colliculus to terminate in the contralateral intermediate grey layer (see Figure 6, sections 1800 to 1000).
As they entered the intermediate grey layer, the nigrotectal axons divided into smaller branches that gave rise to boutons from 1 to 2 pm in diameter (Fig. 9A).
The terminal swellings were aligned in series along the small branches or formed clusters of terminal boutons (Fig. 9B).
In the series, the boutons were often connected by short lengths of very fine fibers (Fig. 9C).
Occasionally, the boutons appeared to be in close apposition to, and even encircling, cell somas (Fig. 9D,E).

The laminar distribution of the nigrotectal terminals was very similar to that of the predorsal bundle cells; although some terminal labeling was present below the intermediate grey layer, the vast majority of the nigrotectal axons terminated within this layer, particularly within the sublayer b (Figs. 6, 7).
The layers below the intermediate grey layer primarily contained axon trunks.

No nigrotectal terminals were seen in the layers superficial to the intermediate grey layer, and the question of the terminal distribution of projections from a lateral subdivision of substantia nigra (May and Hall, '86a; Harting et al., '88) was not addressed.

Results.S: Similar conclusions concerning the terminal distribution of the nigrotectal pathway were obtained with all three tracers.

However, the PHA-L was the most sensitive; many more axons and terminals were labeled in the superior colliculus following nigral injections of PHA-L than following WGA-HRP or HRP injections of a similar size.
The WGA-HRP injections labeled slightly more axons and terminals than injections of HRP alone.
The morphology of the terminal arbors revealed by these different methods was also similar (Fig. 9).
Individual s o n s and terminals could be densely labeled with all three methods and the only difference was in the number of processes labeled.
Nigrotectal terminations on tectospinal cells
Before describing the actual synaptic contacts between nigrotectal terminals and tectospinal cells, we will describe the prominent features of the preand postsynaptic processes.
Fine structure of nigrotectal terminals.
The following description is based on the examination of 110 terminals labeled with WGA-HRP (case 85-105 in Fig. 8) and 58 terminals labeled with PHA-L (cases 87-57 in Fig. 8 and 88-35 in Fig. 7).
Spinal cord injections were not made in these cases.
Tissue from the lateral part of the intermediate grey layer was scanned with the electron microscope and all terminal profiles that included a synaptic contact were photographed.
The grids were not stained in order to make it easier to locate the labeled terminals.
With both methods, labeled terminals were observed in the intermediate grey layer.
Examples are presented in Figure 10.
The terminals were usually from 1 to 2 pm in length along the side making a synaptic contact, but longer lengths were seen where they merged with the fine processes that connect serial boutons.

The nigrotedal terminals typically contained multiple mitochondria and pleomorphic vesicles, and formed synaptic contacts with modest postsynaptic densities that were usually less that 0.5 pm long, Often, the preterminal unmyelinated axon was also filled with pleomorphic vesicles.
The majority (63%) of the terminals contacted dendrites less than 3 pm in diameter.
The remaining terminals contacted either larger dendrites-up to 6 pm in diameter (14%) or somas (23%) with diameters ranging from 8 to 24 pm (mean = 14.1 bm).
The nigrotectal terminals were neither presynaptic nor postsynaptic to other terminals.
In many cases, the nigrotectal terminals were surrounded by unlabeled processes that separated the terminals and their postsynaptic processes from the surrounding neuropil.

Appendages of these processes invaginated into the terminals so that in some sections one or more unlabeled membrane-bound profiles were contained within the profile of the labeled terminals (see Fig. 10B,D).

In a few instances, the unlabeled profiles could be identified as originating from the postsynaptic process or from adjacent synaptic terminals, but in most cases these profiles appeared to originate from the glial-like processes that surround the nigrotectal terminals.
Synaptic contacts between and these unlabeled profiles were the nigrotectal terminals never observed.
Fine structure of tectospinal cells.
Twenty-nine tectospinal cells that were labeled with HRP following injections in the cervical spinal cord were examined with the electron microscope.

The observations confirmed the light microscopic observation that tectospinal cells vary in size and demonstrated further that several features of the fine structure of these cells are correlated with size.
Of particular significance to the present study was a direct correlation between soma size and the density of axosomatic synaptic contacts.
Specifically, in a given section, the largest tectospinal cell somas were contacted by numerous terminals, the medium-size by fewer, and the smallest by only an occasional terminal.
Most of the surfaces of the smaller cell somas were apposed by either other small cells, blood vessels, myelinated axons, or glial cells.
The large and small cells also could be distinguished by their cytoplasmic inclusions.
The largest cells contained a large quantity of cytoplasm, many well-developed Nissl bodies, and a nucleus with a smooth, round profile.
The large cells also often contained fibrillary inclusion bodies (Peters et al., '76); these were located in the cytoplasm adjacent to the nucleus.
In contrast, the medium-size tectospinal cells contained less cytoplasm, smaller Nissl bodies, and a lobulated nucleus.
The smallest tectospinal cells contained very little cytoplasm; a lobulated nucleus occupied most of the soma (Fig. 1).
Sgnaptic contacts between nigrotectal terminals and tectospinal cells.

To characterize the synaptic contacts between nigrotectal terminals and tectospinal cells, we examined tissue from one animal in which a spinal cord injection of HRP was combined with a WGA-HRP injection into substantia nigra (case 88-5, Fig. 8) and one in which the spinal cord injection was paired with a nigral injection of PHA-L (case 88-48, Fig. 8).
In both cases, the distribution of labeled nigrotectal terminals overlapped extensively the distribution of tectospinal cells.

Light microscopic examination of sections from the experiment that used PHA-L as the anterograde tracer indicated that nigrotectal terminals were closely apposed to 73% of the labeled tectospinal cells.
Examination of these cells (n = 40) suggested that the majority of the nigrotectal terminals were closely associated with the dendrites, but that a significant number were apposed to the somas.
Drawings of 14 of these tectospinal cells and their associated nigrotectal terminals are presented in Figure 11.

The majority of terminals that appeared to be closely apposed to the tectospinal cells when examined with the light microscope were found to form synaptic contacts with these cells when they were examined subsequently with the electron microscope.
Thirty-three synaptic contacts between nigrotectal terminals and eight tectospinal cells were examined with the electron microscope.
Several examples are shown in Figures 1,2,12,13, and 14.
In agreement with the observations made with the light microscope, most (21/33) were axodendritic and the remaining (12/33) were axosomatic.
Examples of axodendritic contacts are presented in Figure 13, while examples of axosomatic contacts are shown in Figures 1, 12, and 14.
The fine structure of these terminals and their synaptic contacts was the same as that observed in the cases in which only an anterograde tracer was used.
In particular, the synaptic contacts shown in Figures 12, 13, and 14 illustrate their characteristic pleomorphic vesicles, modest postsynaptic densities, and multiple mitochondria.
The nigrotectal terminals contacted tectospinal cells of different sizes.
The areas of our sample of eight tectospinal cells that were contacted by nigrotectal terminals ranged from 247 to 769 km2 as measured in 50 pm sections through the nucleus.
Even though no relationship was established between the presence of nigrotectal contacts and soma size, tectospinal cells may vary in their amount of nigrotectal input.
Some cells within a dense zone of labeled terminals did not appear to receive any contacts, whereas others received multiple contacts.
Figure 14 illustrates a tectospinal cell that was surrounded by nigrotectal terminals.
The input to this cell was the maximum that we observed in contact with an individual cell.
Control experiments.

TTE.S: In the experiments in whichspinal cord injections of HRP were not paired with an injection in substantia nigra, no labeled terminals were found in the superior colliculus.
In addition, no labeled terminals were found in the control sections from the experiments in which spinal cord HRP injections were paired with PHA-L injections in substantia nigra.
The control sections in these cases were processed with the diaminobenzidine to reveal the HRP reaction product, but were not processed immunocytochemically to reveal the PHA-L.
These two types of controls indicate that the spinal cord did not contribute to the population of labeled terminals we observed in the superior colliculus.

Finally, our cases in which an injection in substantia nigra was not paired with an injection in the spinal cord did not label cells in the superior colliculus, indicating that the nigral injections do not label cells that could be confounded with tectospinal cells in the experiments with paired injections.

Results.S: GABAergic input to predorsal bundle cells
In our material, GAD-immunoreactive terminals were distributed throughout the intermediate grey layer.
With the light microscope, many tectospinal cells labeled with HRP could be seen to have multiple GAD-positive terminals closely apposed to their somas and proximal dendrites.
An example is shown in Figure 15.

Electron microscopic examination of thin sections through tissue containing labeled tectospinal cells and GAD-positive terminals showed that synaptic contacts were made between the labeled terminals and ceils (Fig. 16).

Similar to nigrotectal terminals, the GAD-positive terminals contained pleomorphic vesicles and many mitochondria, and formed synaptic contacts with modest postsynaptic densities on the somas and proximal dendrites of tectospinal cells.
Control sections incubated with preimmune serum instead of the GAD antibody contained no labeled terminals.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

By utilizing the anterograde transport of either WGAHRP or PHA-L in combination with the retrograde transport of HRP, the present study directly demonstrates that the tectospinal component of the predorsal bundle is synaptically contacted by nigrotectal terminals.

Thus, this study confirms the findings of Williams and Faull('88) in the rat and Tokuno and Nakamura ('87) in the cat by demonstrating an anatomical basis for the influence of substantia nigra over tectospinal cells (Chevalier et al., '81, '84, '85).
These methods also allow us to examine the morphology of a large number (201) of nigrotectal terminals and to compare them to the GAD-immunoreactive terminals in contact with tectospinal cells.
We will discuss the functional significance of these observations in later sections.

As the present experiments showed, the anterograde transport of WGA-HRP and PHA-L, when combined with the retrograde transport of HRP, can be used to characterize with the light microscope a terminal arbor in terms of its morphology and its location with respect to the soma or dendritic process of a putative postsynaptic cell, and then, with the electron microscope, to confirm and describe the synaptic contacts formed by the same array of terminals.

Since whenever we saw terminals in close apposition to labeled cells at the light microscopic level, they were found to make synaptic contacts with those cells when examined with the electron microscope, the light microscopic observations were useful or answering questions about the relative distribution of nigrotectal terminals on the dendrites and somas of the cells, about the range in the sizes of cells contacted by the nigrotectal tract, about the percentage of cells that receive nigral input, and, finally, about variations among cells in the density of their nigral input.

Although similar observations were made in our experiments with both anterograde methods, the WGA-HRP method provided better ultrastructural preservation, because higher glutaraldehyde concentrations could be used and because no freezing and thawing of the tissue was necessary.
Nevertheless, we found that the combination of PHA-L with the retrograde transport of HRP was the most powerful for examining the afferent connections of a cell identified by the target of its axon.
The PHA-L method was more sensitive than the WGA-HRP and the preservation of the tissue with the PHA-L method was adequate to examine ultrastructural details of synaptic contacts.

Our confidence that we were indeed examining nigra terminals was increased by the observations that all the terminals had a similar fine structure, and that they resembled the GADimmunoreactive terminals.

In addition, omitting the immunocytochemical step in alternate sections provided a simple and effective control for the possibility that the HRP injections labeled spinotedal terminals that could be mistaken for nigrotectal terminals.
Potential sources of error
The most serious potential sources of error are the possibilities that our procedures labeled terminals in the intermediate grey layer that arose from a structure other than substantia nigra.
We have already mentioned the possibility that the HRP injections in the spinal cord might label spinotectal terminals.

The controls for this possibility were necessary since the spinotectal pathway terminates in the same layer that contains the tectospinal cells (Antonetty and Webster, '751, and since spinotectal cells are located in the region of the spinal cord injections (Edwards et al., '79).

Nevertheless, in our control sections, we were unable to find any terminals in the intermediate grey layer that were labeled by the spinal cord injections, nor were we able to find labeled terminals in more rostral targets of the spinal cord, such as the ventrobasal, posterior, and intralaminar nuclei of the dorsal thalamus.

The absence of significant label in these pathways might be due to a failure of the HRP to transport in sufficient quantity over the distance from the spinal cord to the midbrain and thalamus or, perhaps, to different optimal survival times for the retrograde and anterograde transport.
A similar type of error could result if the substantia nigra injections labeled fibers of passage.

Indeed, in the cat, corticotectal fibers that originate in the prefrontal region leave the cerebral peduncle and then turn dorsal to pass through substantia nigra on their way to the superior colliculus (Segal et al., '83).

Furthermore, physiological studies in the cat have suggested that some of the effects that have been attributed to substantia nigra stimulation are, in fact, results of stimulating these fibers of passage (Karabelas and Moschovakis, '85).
However, involvement of the corticotectal fibers does not appear to be a risk in the rat, since the available evidence suggests that these fibers do not traverse substantia nigra.

In particular, studies using the anteroerade transDort of tritiated amino acids or HR6 from the irefrontal *cortex have shown that the pathway follows a more dorsal, transthalamic route through the ventral and posterior nuclei.
Only the fibers from prefrontal cortex that terminate in substantia nigra or the ventral tegmental region travel in the cerebral peduncle (Beckstead, '79; Hardy, '86).

These results imply that there are separate populations of neurons in prefrontal cortex that project to the midbrain, and that only those that project to the substantia nigra and ventral tegmentum traverse the cerebral peduncle.
This separation of pathways is supported by experiments using retrograde transport to locate the cells of origin of these pathways.

Cells labeled after substantia nigra injections are located in the lateral prefrontal cortex (Bunney and Aghajanian, '76; Gerfen et al., '821, whereas cells labeled following superior colliculus injections are located in the medial prefrontal cortex (Neafsy et al., '86).
Taken together, these studies suggest that it is unlikely that fibers projecting from prefrontal cortex to the superior colliculus were labeled by our nigra injections.

Corticotectal fibers from the more caudal areas of cortex also would not be labeled by our injections, since they leave the peduncles and travel to the superior colliculus without passing through substantia nigra (Lund, '66).
Two other types of evidence provide further support for the argument that substantia nigra is the source of the terminals we observed in the intermediate grey layer.

First, similar distributions of terminals were obtained with both PHA-L and WGA-HRP, and PHA-L, in particular, is less likely to be taken up and transported by fibers of passage (Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84).
Second, with both of these methods, the labeled terminals exhibited a fine structure that is distinct from that observed for corticotectal fibers (Behan, '84).

The differences between the nigrotectal and corticotectal terminal morphologies are not a reflection of the different methods used in the two studies, since trigeminotectal terminals that resemble closely the corticotectal terminals have been labeled using our PHA-L method (Gregory and Hall, '88).
Distribution of predorsal bundle cells and organization of the superior colliculus

The present experiments showed that not only the somata (Bickford and Hall, '89), but also the dendrites of the rat predorsal bundle cells are restricted primarily to the intermediate grey layer, as defined by Weiner ('86).
This laminar distribution of the predorsal bundle cells has significance for our understanding of the organization of the superior colliculus.
Traditionally, the superior colliculus has been divided into superficial and deep zones on the basis of differences in connections and functions (Harting et al., '73; Wurtz and Albano, '80).

While this dichotomy is still useful for distinguishing between the visuosensory and sensorimotor associations of these two tiers, it may at times obscure what appears to be an equally significant division between the intermediate and deep grey layers of the deep zone.
The distribution of predorsal bundle cells in the deep zone provides one basis for this division.

Specifically, retrograde transport experiments in a variety of species have demonstrated that almost all of the predorsal bundle cells are located in the intermediate grey layer (Holcombe and Hall, '81a; May and Hall, '84; Lu et al., '85; Bickford and Hall, '89).

Moreover, HRP injections into the decussation of the predorsal bundle, which fill the dendrites as well as the somas of these cells, show that almost their entire receptive surfaces also are confined to this layer (May and Hall, '84; Lu et al., '85; present experiments), with a limited extension of some distal dendrites into the adjacent layers.

The conclusion that the intermediate grey layer can be distinguished from the deep grey layer by the distribution of predorsal bundle cells also follows from experiments using intracellular injections to examine the morphology and distribution of these cells.
For example, in a study of predorsal bundle cells in the cat, all but a few X cells were located in the intermediate grey layer (Moschovakis and Karabelas, '85).
The exceptional X cells were either in the immediately adjacent part of the deep layer or in a lateral wedge of the deep layer.
The lateral wedge of the deep grey layer resembles a similarly located area in the grey squirrel that contains predorsal bundle cells (Holcombe and Hall, %la; May and Hall, '84).

In studies of the grey squirrel, this wedge was also found to receive inputs that are characteristic of the intermediate grey layer (May and Hall, '84, '86b) and, it could be argued, might most appropriately be considered as forming its ventrolateral tip.
A similar lateral wedge of the deep grey layer receives nigrotectal projections in the cat (Harting et al., '88).
In another study using intracellular methods, Grantyn and Grantyn ('82) found that two-thirds of the predorsal bundle cells they injected in the cat resided in the intermediate grey layer.
Rhoades et al. ('87) appear to have found a comparable distribution in the hamster.

Similarly, in a study of the monkey, all the injected cells were placed either in the intermediate grey layer or the adjacent part of the optic layer, but not in the deep grey layer (Moschovakis et al., '88a).

These studies all support the argument that the intermediate grey layer is the primary source of predorsal bundle cells, and that this is a fundamental distinction between the intermediate and deep grey layers.

In addition, the present experiments showed that one of the predominant gazerelated inputs to the superior colliculus, the projection from substantia nigra pars reticulata, overlaps extensively with the predorsal bundle cells.

The distributions of various other inputs to the deep zone provide further, cross-species support for this distinction, since not only substantia nigra pars reticulata (Graybiel, '78; Beckstead et al., '79; Gerfen et al., '82; May and Hall, '84; Harting et al., '88; Harting and van Lieshout, '91) but also the deep cerebellar nuclei (Roldan and Reinoso-Suarez, '81; Kawamura et al., '82; Sugimoto et al., '82; Uchida et al., '83; May and Hall, '86b; May et al., 'go), the frontal eye field (Kiinzle et al., '76; Leichnetz, '81; Huerta et al., '861, the midbrain tegmentum (Edwards, '75; Moschovakis et al., '88b), the spinal trigeminal nucleus (Huerta et al., '81; Killackey and Erzurumlu, '81; Huerta et al., '83; Gregory and Hall, '88), the spinal cord (Antonetty and Webster, '751, the zonaincerta (Ricardo, '81; Kim et al., '89), and the cholinergic cells of the pedunculopontine tegmental nucleus (Beninato and Spencer, '86; Hall et d., '89) project preferentially to the intermediate grey layer.
Although many of these inputs have a projection to the deep grey layer as well, it is much sparser and more diffusely organized, without patches or other signs of intralaminar organization.
All of the inputs that terminate predominantly in the intermediate grey layer are consistent with the prevailing view that the predorsal bundle cells play a role in initiating orienting movements.

While cells in the deep grey layer may also be premotor in function (Henkel and Edwards, '78; Henkel, '81; Vidal et al., '88; Dean et al., '89) and also give rise to descending-albeit primarily ipsilateral-pathways (Henkel, '81; Holcombe and Hall, '81b; Redgrave et al., '86; Bickford and Hall, '89)) they have their own preferential inputs, including afferents from the supplementary cortical eye field (Heurta and Kaas, '90).

These differences in efferent and afferent connections seem sufficient to propose that the intermediate and deep grey layers are as different functionally from each other as either is from the more superficial layers.
Evidence for parallel efferent pathways in the predorsal bundle

Evidence from several studies suggests that multiple efferent pathways might be distinguished in the predorsal bundle using the same general types of criteria that have been used to distinguish parallel pathways in sensory systems.
For example, in the present experiments, the cells labeled following injections in the cervical spinal cord varied in size.
A recent study of tectospinal cells in rats and hamsters reported a range of sizes similar to those we measured (Sahibzada et al., '87).
In their experiments, the rat tectospinal cell soma areas ranged from 50 to 650 p,m2.
Similarly, Weber et al. ('79) found a wide range of tectospinal cell sizes in the cat.

However, in other studies, the majority of cells labeled by spinal cord injections were either large or from medium to large in size (Castiglioni et al., '78; Huerta and Harting, '82; Murray and Coulter, '82).
To account for the variations in cell size, the argument has been made that cells truncated by the sectioning process might be erroneously counted as small cells (Huerta and Harting, '82).

However, even though truncated cells might account for some of the variation observed in the present study, at least two types of data clearly indicate that small as well as large cells contribute to the tectospinal tract in the rat.

First, labeled cells in the 50 km thick sections often were located near the middle of the section, so that their somas and proximal dendrites could be visualized and recognized as complete, Both large and small cells were observed in this way.

Second, and perhaps most convincing, was the observation in the electron micrographs of small labeled tectospinal cells that had other associated distinguishing features, such as infolded nuclear membranes and a reduced density of somatic synaptic contacts.
Norita ('80) also has noted the relationship between soma size and density of somatic contacts for tectoreticular cells in the cat.
To summarize, the evidence supports the conclusion that tectospinal cells are distributed over a wide size range, and that size is correlated with other features, such as density of somatic contacts.

Recent studies using intracellular injections of HRP to label the efferent cells of the superior colliculus also provide strong evidence that the different cell types contributing to the predorsal bundle can be distinguished by a combination of features, including soma size.

At least two of these types, T and X cells, contribute to the predorsal bundle, but can be distinguished by other features such as size, dendritic fields, sublaminar distribution, and collateral projections (Karabelas and Moschovakis, '85; Moschovakis et al., '88a).
Furthermore, by recording from and then injecting cells in alert monkeys, Moschovakis et al. ('88b) were able to show that T but not X cells discharge before all saccades in their movement field.
More indirect evidence suggests that the X cell category may include the visually triggered saccaderelated cells.
While these studies support the idea that multiple parallel pathways contribute to the predorsal bundle, none directly addresses the question of the significance of the differences in cell size.

If the relationship between cell size and recruitment threshold established for lower motor neurons (Henneman and Olson, '65; Henneman et al., '65a,b; Somjen et al., '65) applies to predorsal bundle cells, the smaller predorsal bundle cells may have lower thresholds for activation.
The relationship found in the present study between soma size and the density of somatic synapses might also influence the order of activation of these cells.

Alternatively, Rhoades et al. ('87) have shown in the hamster that the soma size of predorsal bundle cells is related to both the size of the dendritic field and axon diameter, and therefore must have implications for receptive field organization and conduction velocity.
Finally, predorsal bundle cell size might be related to the differences in terminal density within targets of the predorsal bundle (Grantyn and Grantyn, '82).
Nigrotectal input to predorsal bundle cells
Physiological studies have shown that the nigrotectal tract provides a tonic, GABAergic, inhibitory influence on the premotor cells of the superior colliculus (Hikosaka and Wurtz, '85a).

Shortly before the onset of an orienting movement, the nigrotectal cells are themselves inhibited, allowing the premotor cells of the colliculus to respond with a burst of action potentials and exert their effects on the gaze centers of the brainstem and spinal cord.
Anatomical studies shed light on the morphological basis for this pattern of nigrotectal influence on tectal premotor cells.

In all species that have been studied, the terminal field of the nigrotectal tract overlaps extensively with the cells of the predorsal bundle in the intermediate grey layer (May and Hall, '84; Tokuno and Nakamura, '87; Williams and Faull, '88).

In the rat, the close association between nigrotectal terminals and predorsal bundle cells is further indicated by the finding that the majority of tectospinal cells are located within patches of nigrotectal terminals (Williams and Faull, '88).

We also observed this association between patches of nigrotectal terminals and predorsal bundle cells, and, with maximal labeling of both terminals and cells, found that nigrotectal terminals were closely apposed to 73% of the tectospinal cells.

When eight tectospinal cells were subsequently examined with the electron microscope, the terminals that appeared in the light microscope to be closely apposed to their somas or dendrites were found to make synaptic contact with the cells.
In contrast, in a study of the cat, it was estimated that only 22% of the tectospinal cells are within the patches (Tokuno and Nakamura, '87).

However, this number may underestimate the percent of tectospinal cells that actually receive nigrotectal input, for while cat predorsal bundle cells are distributed throughout the intermediate grey layer (Kawamura and Hasikawa, '78; Grantyn and Grantyn, '82; Lu et al., '85; Moschovakis and Karabelas, '85; Behan et al., '88)) they have larger dendritic fields than do rat predorsal bundle cells and may receive significant input on their distal dendrites (Behan et al., '87).
The experiments using electron microscopy confirm the association between the nigrotectal terminals and predorsal bundle cells.

We observed nigrotectal fibers making synaptic contacts with the somas and proximal dendrites of tectospinal cells and similar results have been reported in studies of the rat and cat that used anterograde degeneration as the marker for nigrotectal terminals and retrograde transport of HRP as the label for tectospinal cells (Tokuno and Nakamura, '87; Williams and Faull, '88).
Since retrograde transport from the spinal cord does not fill the entire cell, the evidence is equivocal concerning the existence of inputs to more distal dendrites.
Nevertheless, the majority of nigrotectal terminals appear to contact small dendrites and it seems likely that at least some of these dendrites belong to predorsal bundle cells.

The finding by Behan et al. ('88) that type I11 terminals make up the majority of terminals on the distal dendrites of predorsal bundle cells, as well as on their somas and proximal dendrites, is consistent with this view.
Type I11 terminals usually range from 0.5 to 1.5 km in diameter, contain pleomorphic vesicles, and make symmetrical contacts with dendrites and cell somas (Norita, '80).
These same features characterize the nigrotectal terminals in the cat (Behan et al., '87).

Two observations support the evidence based on GABA immunocytochemistry and lectin retrograde transport that the nigrotectal synapses on tectospinal cells use GABA as a neurotransmitter (Ficalora and Mize, '89).
First, the distribution of nigrotectal terminals overlaps the distribution of GAD-positive terminals on tectospinal cells.

Second, the ultrastructure of nigrotectal terminals-regardless of whether they were labeled by anterograde transport of WGA-HRP, PHA-L, or tritiated amino acids-is similar to the ultrastructure of the terminals on predorsal bundle cells labeled by the GAD antibodies (present experiments; Vincent et al., '78; Warton et al., '83; Lu et al., '85; Behan et al., '871, that is, in each case the terminals are filled with pleomorphic vesicles, contain many mitochondria, and form synaptic contacts with modest postsynaptic densities.

Taken together, these results provide a morphological basis for the short latency inhibitory effects of substantia nigra stimulation on predorsal bundle cells (Chevalier et al., '84; Moschovakis and Karabelas, '85).
Several other morphological features may be related to the high level of spontaneous activity exhibited by the nigrotectal cells (Hikosaka and Wurtz, '85).
First, the fibers that give rise to terminal boutons often are densely packed with vesicles.
The large number of vesicles within both the terminal boutons and the connecting fibers may be related to a high level of neurotransmitter release.

Second, the large number of mitochondria in the nigrotectal terminals also might indicate a high level of neurotransmitter release, especially since GABA-transaminase, an enzyme used in the metabolism of GABA, is localized primarily in mitochondria (Cooper et al., '82).
Finally, we often observed unlabeled processes of unknown origin surrounding and extending into the nigrotectal boutons.
These processes may be glial in origin and may be involved in the uptake of GABA released at these synapses.

We suggest this role because the GAD-positive terminals that we examined had similar closely associated processes and because glial cells have been shown to take up tritiated GABA in the cat superior colliculus (Mize et al., '81).
Even though our results indicate that most tectospinal cells, regardless of their size, receive nigrotectal input, this does not imply that all tedospinal cells receive equal amounts of input.
Indeed, we observed large variations in the degree to which the somas and proximal dendrites of individual tectospinal cells were contacted by labeled nigrotectal terminals.
These variations may have been due simply to vagaries in the uptake and transport of the tracers, or they may indicate that tectospinal cells vary in their connections with substantia nigra.
The latter alternative is consistent with the results of physiological studies suggesting that not all tectospinal cells are influenced equally by the nigrotectal pathway.

For example, Chevalier et al. ('84) found that stimulation of substantia nigra could depress the excitability of some tectospinal cells, or completely block the ability of others to generate action potentials, or in some cells even delay the invasion of antidromic potentials evoked from the spinal cord.
Karabelas and Moschovakis ('85) also found that substantia nigra stimulation elicits a variety of responses from predorsal bundle cells.
This range of effects could be due to differences in the density of nigrotectal terminals on tectospinal cells.

Consequently, future investigations should be directed toward determining whether nigral inputs are differentially distributed on predorsal bundle cells of different morphologies, and whether the differences are related to the destinations of their axons.
